author: KGW
title: Oregon Caves Chateau on list of America's 'most endangered historic places' - NewsBreak
text:
Cave Junction
Oregon Caves Chateau on list of America's 'most endangered historic places'
3 hours ago
CAVE JUNCTION, Ore. — The Oregon Caves Chateau is among the most "endangered historic places" in the U.S., according to the National Trust for Historic Preservation. The National Park Service owns the landmark, located within the Oregon Caves National Monument and Preserve in southern Oregon. The six-story hotel, built in 1934, includes nearly two dozen unique rooms to rent, a fine dining room and a 1930s-era coffee shop.

author: Sean Bess
title: What God Taught Me About Rest This Year
text:
The week between Christmas and New Year’s Day is a weird one. Most people are off work, or if they’re at work they’re taking it easy. The week is not meant for hustling, meeting deadlines, cramming a million and one items onto a to-do list. Rather, it’s a week of rest.
But it can’t be your only week of rest. You won’t make it through the next 51 weeks if you don’t schedule regular periods of rest. It could be a daily, weekly or even monthly occurrence. But the point is, you need to prioritize rest not only this week but all throughout next year.
It’s a lesson I’ve been learning all year. And it’s one I’ll probably learn about for the rest of my life. Here’s three important truths God has taught me about rest:
Rest is about being a better person
We live in a culture of sensory overload, so it’s no wonder we have a tough time with rest. Someone is reading this article while listening to music, texting a friend and playing Candy Crush. Someone has a YouTube video playing in another window. Someone else has a dozen other tabs on standby, vying for their attention.
Sometimes the most spiritual thing you can do is to do nothing at all. Doing nothing can change everything. Being still and inactive can do wonders for your psyche. Studies have shown that meditation—which I think means sitting in a room with God and seeing who’ll speak first—can make you an all-around better person.
But how many adults do you know who meditate? It seems that the people who could benefit most from silence and solitude are also the least likely to practice it.
We are the generation that starts crawling out of its skin when asked to sit still and remain silent, but once you get a taste of meditation I’m certain you’ll be back for more. It’ll leave you feeling relaxed and revived, as if walking back to your hotel room after a day at the beach. But for those of you who fear silence and dread the idea of being alone or disconnecting from social media, try baby steps.
Psychologist and author Dr. Larry Rosen encourages people to take a few minutes each day to step away from electronics and social media and step into nature. It’s the nicotine patch of rest, but these small steps are better than nothing. Try it. Right now, if you’d like. Step away from the computer screen and step outside. This will all still be here when you get back.
Rest is about being happier
Sadly, some of us will stay busy for the rest of our lives because we worship it. We’ve wrapped our identities up in busyness. We equate being busy with having value.
There’s an episode of Seinfeld in which George Costanza theorized that so long as he looked annoyed his boss would presume that he was hard at work. Like a lot of observational humor, this is a commentary on our culture, and it’s rich with subtext.
We are a busy people. We like that about ourselves. We also hate that about ourselves. Ask someone how they’re doing and you’re likely to hear something along the lines of “I’m busy” or “Things are crazy” or “ACK!” As George Costanza pointed out, we associate being busy with feeling flustered, but being busy also fills a person with a sense of worth because we equate it with being productive.
We take pride in our busyness, but it’s something that chips away at our physical, emotional and spiritual health. We need rest. We need to dial back our busy acts and find some peace.
Rest is about living a better life
Some believe that God made the Earth and cosmos over the course of a few days; others believe it was over the course of several hundred million years. Whatever the case, God rested. After it was all said and done, God took a breather. And it wasn’t because the divine, all powerful creator broke a sweat. Rather, He was introducing a pattern. He was showing us how to live a better kind of life.
We might be helped in our pursuit of rest if we remind ourselves that God doesn’t operate at our frenetic pace. No one has a fuller plate than God—you don’t truly know busy until you’re simultaneously holding the universe together and numbering the hair on peoples’ heads. And yet there are many places in Scripture that mention God sitting on a throne. I love this image. He isn’t checking His phone or pacing back and forth or blustering over a pile of paperwork. He’s sitting.
Follow the Maker’s lead. Take a seat. Turn the volume down. Turn the devices off. Meditate. Rest.

author: glopez
title: Comisión de Diputados aprueba crédito por $us 250 millones para sofocar incendios forestales
text:
Comisión de Diputados aprueba crédito por $us 250 millones para sofocar incendios forestales
Por mayoría absoluta, la Comisión de Planificación de la Cámara de Diputados aprobó este jueves el crédito del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) de $us 250 millones, para las tareas de sofocación de los incendios forestales que afectan al oriente de Bolivia.
El presidente de la Comisión de Planificación, Omar Yujra, exhortó a sus colegas a ratificar la norma en la sesión plenaria de la próxima semana, y hacer a un lado “elementos de corte político y demagógicos”.
Este crédito de $us 250 millones fue canalizado por el BID, para ayudar a la emergencia por desastres naturales y salud pública.
El organismo internacional aprobó el crédito en mayo y el Ejecutivo lo remitió a la Asamblea Legislativa en septiembre.
De acuerdo con el BID este préstamo contingente permitirá ayudar a Bolivia a “construir mayor resiliencia financiera frente a inundaciones, sequías, incendios forestales y posibles brotes epidémicos y pandémicos”.
El crédito se suma a otro por $us 75 millones, facilitado por el Banco de Desarrollo de América Latina (CAF), para también sofocar los incendios. Este segundo crédito es debatido en el pleno de la Cámara de Diputados, en virtud de un acuerdo multipartidario concretado por la presidenta en ejercicio Verónica Challco y que fue avalado por la mayoría de los legisladores en una resolución.

author: Camille Laurent
title: # Restaurant Dr Carla Barber : Torreznos et Four à Bois
text:
Roostiq Marbella : Le nouveau restaurant carnivore validé par Carla Barber Marbella, espagne – 29 Février 2024 – Le nouveau restaurant Roostiq , conçu par Astet Studio, s’impose comme une destination gastronomique incontournable pour les amateurs de viande. Recommandé par l’influenceuse Carla Barber, ce lieu met à l’honneur une cuisine locale et artisanale, avec un service de voiturier gratuit pour une expérience client optimale. L’établissement propose différents espaces, dont une salle privée exclusive, et promet une ambiance élégante et chaleureuse. Découvrez pourquoi ce restaurant suscite autant d’enthousiasme et ce qui le rend si spécial.
Voici une analyse du texte que vous avez fourni, en mettant l’accent sur les aspects pertinents pour un résumé ou une recommandation :
Points Clés sur roostiq :
Conception des Locaux : Élégante et chaleureuse, conçue par Astet Studio.
Environnements : Dispose de plusieurs espaces : bar, salon principal, terrasse et une réserve exclusive appelée Roostiq Privé (idéal pour les dîners intimes ou célébrations).
Services Additionnels : Offre un service de voiturier gratuit, soulignant l’importance de l’expérience client.
Recommandation par Influenceur : Carla Barber, connue pour son style de vie sain et sophistiqué, a recommandé Roostiq sur Instagram, le qualifiant de “notre site” pour les carnivores. Cette recommandation a généré beaucoup d’interactions.
Philosophie : “Nous cultivons”. Ils cultivent leurs propres légumes, élèvent leurs animaux et fabriquent leurs saucisses. Approche Culinaire : Met l’accent sur l’écologique et l’artisanal, proposant des plats “honnêtes, savoureux et durables”. L’objectif est d’exciter par l’essentiel plutôt que par l’artifice.
Roostiq est présenté comme un restaurant à Marbella qui allie une décoration soignée à une philosophie axée sur la production locale et artisanale. Sa recommandation par une influenceuse comme Carla Barber renforce son attrait, particulièrement pour les amateurs de viande.
Hashtags suggérés :
#Roostiq #Marbella #restaurant #Gastronomie #CuisineLocale #Artisanal #Ecologique #Recommandé #CarlaBarber #BonnesAdresses
